Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Sam, my closest friend. I read it twice—he thought I was annoyed with him, all because my last text was too blunt. His reply was clipped, and I could feel the hurt behind his words. I knew I should call him right away, clear things up before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do: communicate, fix things before they fester.

But just as I reached for my phone, my work line rang. It was the contractor for the new library project, and I could hear the urgency in his voice. There was a delivery mix-up, and if I didn’t sort it out now, the whole schedule would slip. As the architect, it was my job to keep everything running smoothly, to be available and decisive.

I stared at both phones, feeling the pressure build in my chest. My friend needed reassurance, but my team needed direction. I couldn’t do both at once. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of being a good friend and a responsible architect, knowing that whichever call I made first, I’d be letting someone down.
